aw2JzDkTT8Fq4zomP5u8fA.text: Well... don't get me wrong, food was good, in fact quite damn delicious, but the deliciousness to price ratio definitely would keep me from coming back... often. If I'm back in Merry Ol' England, I'll definitely try have another go at it.

B6Wir6ck0mu1QgWJY2EBvw.text: We dined here with some pretty high expectations, we left disappointed.I get the whole Tapas style dinning and have dined all over the world but the extremely small portions and the overly proud high prices are almost laughable. Service was overdone and pretentious and had to ask for items several times.  I really wanted to like this place but Ramsey missed the mark on this one

gDQV-JacRwRgjL4v4C87Og.text: While visiting London, my husband and I made it a point to visit one of Gordon Ramsay's restaurants. We went for a late dinner at Maze Grill. You should know that Maze Grill has essentially a steak menu - so I would not recommend it for vegetarians. My husband is Argentinian, and he knows his steak, so it was perfect for him.The menu has a selection of various cuts of steak from various regions in the UK, US and Japan. It was a tough decision to select the cuts of meat - I wanted to try them all to taste the difference. It would have been great to have tasting platter of the various steaks, so I would suggest going with group instead to get the variety.  The steaks were cooked to perfection, however my husband believed the portions could have been larger. Service could have been better, but as we were probably the last seating before kitchen close, I'm assuming everyone was ramping down. We just missed a sighting of Chef Ramsay by a couple of days.  Overall, it was a great experience and I would go back again.

y_oroB_CD3sE8gIH9FBdzQ.text: We ate on the grill side of the restaurant.  We were really disappointed.  The service was TERRIBLE.  I could not believe how hard it was to get the attention of the waiter at any given time.  Atmosphere was bad. It was about 1000 degrees.  You expect some of this with the grill and open kitchen however you would also expect that the restaurant would have better ventilation.The food was good but disappointing for the price.  Frankly the dessert was a total miss.  I would not recommend to friends.

wNnllJ5eRj6PrDd_Q9Wb4Q.text: When i ventured here the other evening the place was bustling, which is always good to see at half 7 on a weekday. The bar area seemed busy, but when we left was very sparse! We sat on the raised seating, and went for the chefs menu which was made up from 7 courses, which for a tasting menu was very adequately portioned! All the portions are served at tasting menu size which is quite different. The food when it came was amazing, and just the right mixture of modern, fine tasty food. They also offer wine flights, which consist of 3 complimentary wines served at once on a little wine holder tree (i'm not sure there is a word to describe this) which is a very fancy idea. The staff were all really clever at knowing their stuff & friendly. the excution of serving seemed ever so efficient. I loved the atmoshphere in this place, and we could see into the kitchen through a huge glass window which is great for someone as nosey as me! It all seemed very relaxed front of house, but can be sure that kitchen looked like no fun was being had!!

dGgP82Q0UL3tPvxA4I9mpQ.text: Truly one of the best lunches I've ever had (and of course, one of the most expensive). I opted to do a la carte small plates instead of the tasting menu. Our server said that 4 dishes is usually what most people eat. I went for two because usually portions are much bigger than they lead on. Not so much here! I ended up having to order more. However small the food may be, the flavour makes up for it in abundance Some favourites:-Duraude with lobster risotto-Pumpkin latte with duck-Quail Wine list by the glass was very good. It was definitely worth the price, but I won't be going back until my wallet has had some time to recover.

LnFWpWgSjZata9PrrijMCQ.text: Well obviously your going to be expecting perfection from a Gordon Ramsay restaurant when you go there. And perfection is pretty much exactly what we got. Why the four star? Well, I do admire to extremely large variety and types of cuts you can get at this place. Red meat made to melt in your mouth at a wonderful medium-rare. Perfect each time we have gone. But.. I just don't think I can justify, even though I have, buying a  NY steak for 140 US dollars. It was wonderful, bliss, don't get me wrong; but when I had the cheaper Rib-eye steak, I have to say the price difference really could not be found. All in all, best steak house I've ever been too! This will always be a place we will visit each time we're in town. Expect perfection here because it will be found.

Yu8JJHLGjwjbszdG5uEagg.text: I've been back to Maze twice in the past couple of months (I go to London on business every 6 weeks or so) and I have to say, I'm over it.  While I love the wait staff, including the bartenders, I'm just not willing to pay the over-the-top prices for a few bites of food per entree.  The food is good, but not that good.

1Ej_ftdAd37BtZKHUNVDCg.text: Outstanding service. Inventive and attractive dishes. Modern decor. Lunch can be very economical, despite the high amount of workmanship obviously required. I enjoyed the experience & food at Maze.

TNKM15lU01kqc2KX-aFkwQ.text: Jason Atherton has done a superb job at Maze. I can safely say it is one of the best places in London that i have been to dine. It was a special occasion as my mum turned 50 and we went for the full 9 course set menu. The food was imaginative and most importantly tasty. The service, as you would expect from a Gordon Ramsay establishment was impeccible. I counted 5 seconds between my wine glass emptying to it being refilled again. Due to the special occasion we were offered to be shown around the kitchen and watch the slick work being done by the friendly kitchen staff. Highly recommended for a special occasion.

U0Rmww-5KsDrE2FNqLdyyg.text: A few weekends back, my sister and I had lunch at Maze with our cousin and her husband, with their 1-yr old baby and her mother-in-law. They had finished their 2 year secondment in Oxford, and were returning to Melbourne, so we decided to have a celebratory farewell lunch. Maze were very accommodating, and they had a high-chair for the baby. Staff were very helpful, polite and attentive. Service was impeccable, and the best I've seen at restaurants so far. Plates and cutlery were changed after each course, which is impressive, considering that they use silver cutlery, which has that lovely metallic tinge. We also had a bottle of San Cerre, and this is the first place I've seen that decants white wine. Bread was replenished regularly throughout the meal, and although they only served two types of bread in a metal cup, they were tasty. One was an elongated finger-shaped soft bread lightly sprinkled with salt, and the other was a slightly harder oval-shaped roll. For the meal, I had the (1) Orkney scallops with Pink Fir potatoes, cauliflower and summer truffles; (2) Quail with kohlrabi, cauliflower, and a burnt onion reduction; (3) Roasted Muntjac deer with pine nut purée, baby beets, oats, seeds and juniper; and (4) Peanut butter and cherry jam sandwich, tonka bean cream and dehydrated cherries.I chose the scallops because I'd seen them on the website, and wanted to try them. I also love peanut butter, and was curious to see how it could be used in fine dining. The scallops were served on a nice glass plate, 3 lovely scallops on a bed of pureed cauliflower, with slices of potatoe and shavings of truffle. The flavours weren't overpowering, and allowed the flavour of the scallops shine through. The scallops were firm but not rubbery or overcooked. A very enjoyable dish.The quail was very delicate, and the cauliflower was crumbled into something that resembled cous-cous. I wasn't exactly bowled over by this dish, and would consider it just average. Nothing to shout about.The Muntjac deer was a clear winner. The meat was a deliciously medium pink, served with a lovely thick, flavourful puree. The oats and seeds in the puree added a nice crunchy texture and a nutty flavour, which I felt complemented the deer excellently. The beets provided a lovely tangy contrast to the meat. Putting a bit of everything on a fork, made the flavours dance across my tongue and all over my mouth. I thoroughly enjoyed this dish. It was very rich, so although the portion looked small, it was quite filling (maybe because this was already my 3rd dish).To finish off, the peanut butter and cherry jam sandwich I had was divine. About 2.5 to 3 inches of lovely smooth creamy peanut butter mousse in a cylindrical shape was sandwiched between two round discs created from caramelised sugar. A thick cherry jam/liquid was then poured over this sandwich. There was also a nice dollop of tonka bean cream, but I was just focused on the peanut butter. It had plenty of peanut butter flavour, and the rich creamy taste was well balanced with the acidic cherry jam. The caramelised sugar discs provided a nice crunch. I was glad I chose this and will definitely be coming back again just to have this dessert.We then had coffees, and they served a little platter of petit fours with the coffee. A nice way to finish off the meal. Not cheap, but as a treat, it was a fantastic experience, and one I thoroughly enjoyed. It's less formal than Gordon's other restaurants, and has a more relaxed atmosphere, which allows diners to enjoy their food, instead of worrying about formalities.

-wzt3BmkagYq_imfnujJIQ.text: I'd obviously heard quite a bit about Maze, and as such was quivering both in anticipation of the scrumptious treats ahead and with fear of what it was going to do to my pocket...Well, I needn't have worried on the cost part, true we were eating in Maze Grill rather than Maze proper, but the cost for three courses was an extremely reasonable £21 for a 3 course lunch... Phew!  Saying that we did splash out on a bottle of wine which essentially doubled the price of the meal between the 3 of us.So onto the food...  My dining companions started with the lentil & bacon soup and I have to say that when it arrived I felt a twinge of food envy, not that my smoked eel on golden beetroot wasn't a perfectly balanced and tasty dish, but the soup looked more filling and by the time our starters had arrived I was truly ravenous!For our main we all imaginatively plumped for the rump... And it was delicious, perfectly cooked, deliciously tender (for rump) I'd definitely have it again.And then things went slightly awry...  The service which had been excellent up until this point somehow evaporated and we were left waiting over 30 minutes for our (admittedly still delicious) desert, Gordon would not have been happy and neither was I, defintely lost a star there Maze Grill...

ZW8On88Qv-IRK5PNxXs5tQ.text: I think not that good as a lot of people say but still ok

oeLDYtRKugw6hPPLe5wyCQ.text: Came for tasting menu at lunch, which saves a fortune. Delicious & innovative food; attentive, efficient, but not intrusive staff. Great variety on the tasting menu.

b6GM7N6ZF1J1YBDTSjCFdQ.text: This is my first Gordon Ramsay restaurant, I give it a B.Chilled watercress soup  with cured sea trout - was too saltySome crab dish - plainRoasted Hake (fish) - not bad, sauce was good.pork medley - getting better, again had really good sauceRosemary buttermilk pannacotta with strawberry jelly and black olive caramel - yummmmshared cheese - cheese is always goodDevon milk and yogurt mousse with berry sorbet - pretty goodshared bitter chocolate delice with honey gelatine and honey ice cream wow, high percent of cacao in that chocolate, the honey ice cream compliments the dark dark chocolate very well.Not really much to say about this place, I wouldn't go here again. If you happen to be a vegetarian they do have a special chef tasting menu for you.anitaeat.com

Bq4mkTHxuZ76EsuCMp8ofQ.text: Ah yes, Gordon Ramsay's. It is not my custom to dine in establishments of this kind, so I couldn't really say how this one compares to other top class restaurants. For me it was more a question of  is it worth it spending 70-80 quid on a meal? (that's the minimum amount you can expect to spend per person if you come here in the evening, unless you're not having any wine, but why on earth would you do that to yourself.) My answer to that question is a firm yes. We should all indulge in some Michelin-starred food now and then. Don't waste your time on those restaurants in the medium price range, eat cheap, save up and go to Gordon Ramsays! It's not only about the food - which of course, it has to be said, is exquisite (Maze specialises in delicate tasting-sized dishes, each dish is like a little piece of art) - it's about the whole experience. The restaurant itself is exceptionally stylish and elegant - modern, with lots of shiny surfaces, yet friendly and inviting - and the service is just fantastic. The waiters are many and extremely attentive (they keep filling up your wine glass almost after every sip you take), and whether you eat here every week or once in a blue moon they do their best to make it a special occasion for you. No snobbery in sight. Hmmmm, might come here for lunch sometime. There's a set menu, either about 30 quid for four courses or 40 for 6. Almost cheap! Well, maybe not. But now I'm hooked!

6yYf8__2c3bcbgXA1LLoow.text: Chic decor and dainty dishes with a British-Asian flavour fusion. Prices not unreasonable for the West End but add a premium for bearing the Gordon Ramsey association. Fun once or twice but I find it hard to become a regular. HOWEVER... the kitchen table is the best I've been to. Comfortably seats 6 for £600 (when I first went a year ago). The kitchen tour was fun and the scene full of action and drama, plus a better menu (I thought) than the one I'd had in the main dining room. Definitely one of the finest dinner-theatre experiences I've ever had.

_tQxR9LkMos7ER_NZZAsXQ.text: I wished for so much more. This review will likely need to be discounted due to the odd nature of the meal and the general bizarreness of the evening. To start, we had a private room for 25, so that's a bit unusual for your average diner, and got something that looked like an 8 course prix fixe for everyone attending. The second point to note is that weirdly, before we'd started the power in the restaurant went out, it came back on eventually, but it was auspicious.I'll do this somewhat in reverse in terms of themes, but it may be helpful to have an idea how my evening at maze worked chronologically. Opens with going to the lobby, being led through the main restaurant through the hotel lobby to our private room, realize there's 3 out of 25 of us with everyone else likely late or at the bar we trek back the way we came past the restaurant lobby to the bar, we are at the bar for some light drinking then trek back to our room for more light drinking followed by a seated meal.Décor - the main dining space is much nicer looking than the GR website makes it look (in my opinion). Its not so brightly lit and doesn't come off so airport lounge-y as I was expecting. The bar area is similarly attired but is an awkward space with strange seating patterns and no great area to stand with drinks and mill around. The private room, looked marginally nicer than a small hotel conference room (which is likely its other function, this is in a hotel after all) due to the wine refrigerators, but the subterranean space couple with odd windows and a lack of notable décor made it feel less than poshService - generally excellent during the meal service. This is to be expected considering the vast sums of money our benefactors were bestowing on the GR empire so that doesn't really more the needle much. One thing that did irk me was when at the bar, enough of our party arrived where we though we ought to adjourn into our dining chamber. So we're still in the middle of our drinks and we start to move through the route necessary to locate us in our room and our waitress halts us telling us we cannot leave the bar area with our cups, our drinks must be finished before we depart. Now I understand this is a big-ish restaurant, or at least big enough to have separate rooms for bar and dining as opposed to being 2 parts of the same room, but we noted to our waitress that we had a private room, so clearly she knows we're dropping serious coin and she felt it still necessary to take this take. Not hugely annoying, but kindof tacky and for the prices, honestly absurd upon sober reasoning.Food - between the pre-dinner drinks at the bar, the champagne pre-dinner, and the wine, the food was a bit of a blur. I will say I found it clever, well paced and flavorful. The downside is, maybe its too much wine to the head, but it wasn't that memorable. The one thing that stuck out to me was a mushroom veloute, I'm not generally a fan of mushroom soups, but this was exquisite. The rest, sigh, not particularly notableOverall - its tough to get a proper read on the place, considering I didn't order anything on my own, I didn't pay for anything, and it was an overall unusual dining experience, but hopefully this stands as a useful note to anyone else who finds themselves in a position to pick a big group dinner

tueaGH2NwA99TclGL0Yk8w.text: Been to Both Maze and Maze Grill on several Occasions, The Food in both is consistently not just perfect but amazing.I will review both in this as people seem to be mixing the 2 restaurants on qype, I will start with Maze, the Marinated beetroot, Sairass cheese, is not what i would have normally ordered but was recommended by staff at Ramsay's gastronomic pub 'The Narrow' (see my other review) and was an out of this world dish. Other favourites include, Daurade with squid Bolognese, chorizo, garlic and lemon puréeCornish lamb rack and shoulder, English garden mint gel Rump of veal, tasting of artichokes, leek and truffleIn fact every dish is simply a discovery into the joys of food. The Staff here are above professional and at the same time friendly, The Wine and champagne list is superb and for that special occasion (or everyday occasion ) You will be hard pushed to find Cristal 2002 at a Restaurant in London for their amazing price of a little over £200 let alone in a Michelin Starred restaurant of this calibre! Out the door pass Reception and you will find yourself in Maze Grill a great place for those who appreciate a good steak, If you are amongst the blind that think that Gaucho's serve a good steak then Maze Grill is an education on steaks, What have I got against Gaucho yes they know how to cook a steak i will give them that but unfortunately what they are cooking is 'Finest Argentinean Steak' the only problem with that is their is nothing that fine about Argentinean Cattle it is tasteless at best, Yes i have been to several and having tried the sampler which is all 5 cuts none have come close to impressing me, But back to Maze grill as all that should be for another review and what you find is the finest breeds from the Uk and around the world, We have some of the tastiest Steak on our doorstep(with few exceptions like Kobe more later) so why eat a cow that Diego Maradona has kicked over from Argentina, Breeds include Casterbridge grain fed, Hereford grass fed, Aberdeen Angus, and for those who want to go further a field Creekstone prime U.S.D.A. corn fed, aged 35 days as well as Wagyu(Yes From Cows that are massaged played music too etc) Prices are all very reasonable the price of Wagyu may shock some at around £100 but you will not find 9th grade any cheaper anywhere I know. Not the Largest steaks in the World but if you are often compared to a pig like me then even 2 of the normal breeds would not break the bank and is nice to compare tastes. All the sides and fish are also amongst the best and deserts are amazing too.This and Hawksmoor are the only 2 places in London i would recommend to meat lovers, Of course if in New York Or Las Vegas(know there are a few more in the U.S but have only been to these too ) there is Del frescos but that is a whole other story. Maze and Maze Grill get into my top 5 every time.

S4hFZtr6HW9NobYzq6XPMQ.text: We had a fantastic time here and couldn't recommend it highly enough. The food was tops, we had a six course fixed menu - mostly small dishes, but you're not left feeling hungry at the end. The red wine I had was also very tasty! The service was great from the friendly staff, and we even got a special little birthday cake at the end! While it's a Gordon Ramsay restaurant, I think the head chef is Jason Atherton, who often appears on some TV cooking shows. Yes, it is quite expensive in the grand scheme of things, but you would hopefully have a great time and it would be worth doing it for a special occasion!

zIiCynj6Aw308xUfddHUdg.text: Nice place and meal. £30 for 4 course is very good, we booked a table by the window, and will go there again!

9JFzkqxg1ufOqFDkn9PANA.text: Excellent service and very good food. Nothing surprising (perhaps I expected too much), but everything was very good. The staff very well trained and always smiley. I ordered the tasting menu. The only thing I didn't like too much were the desserts... And the venison was excellent. Worth one Michelin star, but no more.

ppKtYFKQVkiJWg94pt5tng.text: Food quality is out of this world. Also have some nice cocktails. Perfect for a special occasion!

P3t3wubgF4GVXvqQNypLjw.text: Ate on the grill side with a group of 8, and had an amazing time.  We had the "chef's table" right by the kitchen and got to see all the action.  The prawns with chili sauce appetizer was incredible.  The bone in ribeye was cooked perfectly.  The grills used here are charcoal, so you get a natural, smoky flavor.  It came with roasted garlic cloves,  which i squeezed and rubbed on my steak.  John, the manager, was witty and ensured we had a great experience.  We were even given a tour of the kitchen at the end of the night.  I highly recommend this restaurant, especially for a larger group.  Food and service is exceptional

620zwuyztzO4fz3tEs2bgg.text: Expectation was quite high due to Gordon Ramsay restaurant however was quite dissapointing with the group menu. Of course all is pre-booked and none of us was able to change the menu.  We were given Groups Menu 3 which consists of:  I) Roasted parsnip soup and toasted chestnuts II) Grilled quail with crispy bacon and stilton, III) Slow braised short rib, creamed mash potato, steamed spinach and red wine sauce IV) Sticky toffee pudding and Devonshire clotted cream. It is about £65.00 per person without drinks. First of, I don't think everyone love quail :( some of the colleague didn't event touch the bird.  The top part of the short rib was so hard to chew and has lotsa fats. Yiew... The sticky toffee pudding was super sweet but what can I say, it is dessert, it meant to be. :) I think the next time I visit this restaurant I probably try something else.. Let's see.

AEiPsGPkXaqAVNjC7m4t5A.text: One week ago I had the most amazing lunch of my life so far......at this restaurant!So I make the trip to London and decide to surprise my ex-pat foodie friend with a celebrity chef lunch. We were not disappointed!I had the four course sampler menu with wine pairings.....Wild Garlic Soup, Veal Shin, Pork Belly and a nice raspberry something HEAVEN as a last course. I was sold with the soup.....amazing taste, layers upon layers of flavor, beautiful presentation and excellent service. It's difficult to describe such complex flavors but let's just say the chef was a genius!Surprisingly casual, unpretentious and comfortable. One of the best meals I have ever had. My foodie friend agreed with foodie orgasmic delight. Very pricey. We both had a pre-meal cocktail, the four courses with wine, cappuccino and a grappa. Amazing!

photos.caption: Photo of maze Grill Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

iE9wiMNAKlnFa2_5f1xrNA.text: Lunch for one. Nice atmosphere. Was a bit turned off that my server took so long to great me, but the food made up for it. I ordered the Dumpling of Lobster and Sushi Platter. Both were very good. Loved the Tuna and Salmon. I'm not a dessert fan, but ordered the lemon tart that was very refreshing! Thanks Gordon.

qkdLBoL4LJEygE6G32NNJA.text: Gordon, you eccentric chap. I went into Maze, not expecting much, assuming it might just be another celebrity chef dining experience that is overhyped and overpriced. But no no, I was wrong. Maze has proven me wrong. Selling point #1: iPad wine menu. *ching ching ching* Immediate win in my books and mucho puntos for you Gordon. Selling point #2: Great service from a cute server with great stories. Our server was so entertaining, telling us stories of when Gordon comes to the restaurant and how he is exactly as he is on TV. Nod your head, say Yes Chef, do not talk back to Gordon!Selling point #3: Actual great food. I do love the tapas style menu, small tasting portions so you get to try a larger variety. What stood out to me was: yellow fin tuna, squab pigeon foie gras, halibut, duck breast and...... the lemon refresher & tart. Love love love the smell of lemon. Although, I did thought the basket of lemon was somehow the dessert. It was soaked in liquid nitrogen so it gives off the smoke.... but it's just for the smell and you eat the tart that comes along with it. A bit gimmicky but i love it. For the price and service, oh so worth it. Well done Gordon. Well done.

Vt5n-sXaiRkHlwX8id-_Gg.text: This review is for Maze Grill - I've never been to Maze.Best steak I've ever eaten in the UK and really not overpriced.  Last time here I had the the Dedham Vale Sirloin (£33) - just amazing.  Only thing that could have made this 5 star is if they had a better range of veg on offer for those of us who don't always want chips with our steak  - only spinach on the menu.

ZRvPPCO3mJ30YSY3t98nXQ.text: I'm surprised that this restaurant is so busy yet there is only one other Yelp review. I had a delicious grilled salmon with a side of fries and a green salad. It was pretty tasty. The fish was well prepared, not over cooked and juicy.They brought toasted bread to the table which was awkward. One bite and crumbs everywhere. I liked the bread but would have preferred warmed but not toasted.Service was friendly and inviting.

x-epPplZ0DKdUjtyYAm8ww.text: I was really impressed by the entire chef tasting menu at Maze. A few of the more memorable courses:Starting with the broccoli stilton soup - the broccoli wasn't overcooked, just al dente so there were big chunks, and there was a sharp bite from the stilton foam on topduck foie gras - extremely smooth and luxurious and I loved the sauternes gelLobster, prawn, and salmon wonton soup-smelled absolutely wonderful and really warmed the heart. Great flavor in the filling and nice delicate noodle wrappingVenison with risotto and butternut squash- it was cooked to perfect at a medium rare to rare temperature. It was a healthy portion and very tender. The accompaniment of the butternut squash went perfectlyDessert - don't remember exactly what it was but it was like a dark chocolate mousse with mango ice cream. It was extremely rich and wonderful thoughThe service was great. The people very nice. The atmosphere was cool, not too loud. I really enjoyed me meal here.

_4Flx7F67AVY5DzTtZBHOQ.text: We dined at Maze and while service and food was well presented, there was an element missing. The dining room was well spread with a glimpse from our table of the active kitchen. We opted for the tasting menu with a flight of wine to compliment. Again everything was nice but with a £220 bill with service to boot I left feeling there are more whole dining experiences to be had.

MSyWuO9OVe4gKwcl3zjGCQ.text: The restaurant and bar are very attractively appointed and quite busy on a Saturday night. Our party of 6 was seated after having a drink in the bar. Perhaps about 15 minutes after our reservation time. Not bad for a popular place on a Saturday night. Our party ordered two bottles of wine one in the $250 range. The other was about $800. It was difficult to find to similarly priced bottles. The wine list was not the best. We hadn't expected to order in the higher range. The list was very different from the one published on the website. Our first course of fried calamari was inedible. It was so rubbery it couldn't chewed. They replaced it but the second try wasn't much better. The roasted pumpkin soup was much too salty and not hot just warm. The Maze sushi was much better the fish was very fresh but the rice didn't hold together when picked up with chopsticks. Everyone enjoyed the steaks they ordered. All were cooked as ordered. The sides were fine. I ordered the whole sea bass which was cooked well. I needed to filet my own which I Expected but I would expect a Gordon Ramsey restaurant to provide the appropriate knife for the job not the huge place knife I was given. The fennel orange salad was very large pieces of butter or iceberg lettuce dressed with very old tasting oil. No sign of fennel or orange and a giant mess on the plate. Because Gordon Ramsey is such a presence on TV and such a stickler for perfection I expected more, especially at this price. We were not in a pub.Deserts were fine with a decent presentation. Unfortunately we wouldn't rush back.

0AuKUUuV1kzUrX7PYPr01Q.text: I was here last year around this time of year. The only thing you should be getting at the Maze is steak. I made a slight mistake of ordering the lobster and bone marrow dish (don't get me wrong, it was still yummy. I also don't think this is available anymore...), but when I had a bite of my friends Wagyu '9th grade' Gold style steak...the lobster couldn't compare. Grilled to perfection, that was one handsome piece of steak! Dessert was so-so, it was pretty hard to be impressed with anything else after that beef. The only cravat was that service that day was a little rude, I don't think they approved of us going family style and moving the plates around. Otherwise, gold claps all around.

vsUUnR1xUevh3Qw3VmdTTA.text: I read the reviews, so I made the reservation with high hopes. I went there with my husband and my little girl. The service was very nice, but the dishes were not as good as I imagined. I had salmon tataki, tuna for appertizer, lamb, scallops, dumplings, beef for main courses. All of them tasted a little fusion and Asian.

VolMqE5o2ZYhKslO_iRmmQ.text: The restaurant was located in our hotel. It was a prix fixe menu that night. The food was average, the restaurant was romantic and the service was great!  And I can say we ate at Gordon Ramsey's restaurant in London!

JJIaMQsxjrPAabUinyAMVQ.text: The best steak I've had in London, superb meaty flavours, tender and cooked to perfection.  It was a nice touch to bring out the different steaks before ordering so you could see the difference.  It's a "poshish" place but the waiter and sommelier were not stuffy and friendly.  Desert was great too even though I don't have a sweet tooth.  A great place to take someone who loves steak on a special occasion.

KEhC8vBgFvLivwljSVDNaQ.text: There are really two parts to Maze - the grill and the sushi bar. We visited the grill and were quite disappointed. The food was good and well prepared. We had squid and whitebait as appetizers. I had a steak and my wife had salmon as mains. We split a creme brulee for dessert.What we did not like was the service. We were staying at the hotel and expected to get some priority in seating. We were told 30 minutes but it took over an hour to get a table. In the meantime, we went to the bar were the service was impossibly slow and I had to go and hunt down drinks. The real kicker came with the bill a £2 cover  charge and 12.5% service charge. As a friend of mine said, Gordon is just taking the piss.

t-5w7hQ24naDP759bgbZ6g.text: Great disappointment from Great  G Ramsay, We have been fans of THE CHEF for quite some time. But food was average and for this money I would rather go to Nobu or ROKA. Nothing was really impressively. Small  balls made our raw pear were part of  one dish and it was a hunt with forks which ended in praying that we manage to pierce it with our cutlery and not explain ourselves to table next to us as to why our food lands on them. We didn't order desserts as the meal was so bad that bill was enough to make us run. We decided not to risk the dessert outcome and we went to FOUR SEASONS HOTEL for nice chocolate mousse. Sorry Gordon but we wasted our money on your joint. I would rather go and eat at ROKA or NOBU where  we can always count on great experience.

1Gkosu28Enbk0eGfanMl-g.text: I'm sorry to leave a negative review, but this dinner was just not up to par.  Fortunately, we seem to be the outliers, but it was not a great experience.  I think diners have realized this isn't the best though, as when we arrived we realized the restaurant was far from full at 7:45 pm (and never got any fuller through the night).  Other Mayfair restaurants were packed this night, partly why we selected this restaurant (we needed a quick, same day reservation).  The food was pretty good but:- they forgot to prepare our meals.  We had received our appetizers but nothing else. Long after our food was due we were told it would be right out. 20 minutes later and almost an hour from our first course our dinner arrived.  - for the wait we were offered a tour of the kitchen. This sounded great.  At the end of the meal, excited for the tour, we were told that instead the chef had signed menus for us.  I really had no need for a menu signed by a chef that prepared our okay dinner- mediocre wine list.  Yes they have the big names, Opus One, the big name grand crus, etc, but we expected a broader list for the restaurant. - we were on the main floor. There is a level above this floor that looks over to this area.  We felt a bit creeped out by the staff just standing and watching from overhead.- when we made our reservation online it said that for our time slot there was a four course menu. It's partially why we booked the time we did.  When we arrived we were told this was offered earlier, and not at our time slot. As a side note, the menu displayed outside has more offerings than the actual menu. Some pluses: - some of the entrees were okay (asparagus salad), but some were very, very good (scallops) - this is why I gave it 2 stars. - staff was very nice and dressed well- we were seated promptly- our drinks were full w/out asking- they had Reidel glassware, including the appropriate glasses for our Bordeaux.  We will not go back here, and likely not to another Ramsay establishment, though understand others love this place.  Hope you have better luck than us!

iYHAY01DlQev_bBVeWGO9g.text: Nice atmosphere, nice sashimi(snow crab is good),octopus could be more tender( the one I had tonight was really chewy, maybe too chewy), beef tatami is below expectation, duck leg is juicy and tender, pork belly is okay, frozen yogurt(tastes really natural and flavourful) is better than blood orange cake(too dense)

wUGZLnTAuS8xSdfl3RVwWw.text: I'm generally not a fan of small plates, and that's probably why I found this restaurant to be just okay. The vibe of the restaurant was nice- chill and casual, but classy. The food didn't blow us away. I went with the mushroom risotto, tuna, and lobster dumpling.  The risotto was okay, texture was fine, wasn't super tasty.  The tuna was also not very exciting. Lobster dumpling I thought was underwhelming in terms of taste.  I thought that the items I tried neither highlighted the ingredients nor showcased the preparation of the dishes. It was kind of a bore scene. We shared a few of the desserts, but again no standouts. I wouldn't really recommend this restaurant. The food not only doesn't justify the price tag, it's also not very tasty.

ro2nD4Nn0cIJ7NbCRDlcRg.text: This is the kind of very rare really bad places where they take away your drink while you haven't finished it yet, hoping you're gonna order another one! At those prices,  they allow themselves that? The place is finished, don't waste your hard earned money in this tourist trap.

_JkBZRn9cePZTrNcBr5ohQ.text: Poop. Don't waste your money. I went here for my birthday and was severely disappointed. I hold true the belief that Gordon Ramsey's restaurants are poop with crap service. Even though I booked they put me on a bar stool

lnYH--QPTNt7nFKH--muVg.text: Bloody brilliant restaurant by Gordon Ramsay in London.  Best, BY FAR, restaurant in the UK.  Everything we had was full of flavor and the service was marvelous.  I had an absolute delicious meal.We did the Chef's tasting.  Everything was terrific!

cQ3ElDgtnisqJu32nOT-vA.text: Beautiful food and lovely drinks to compliment! From start to finish our visit was amazing and well worth it. We had the 4 course set menu for lunch which had a great selection. To start I ordered Beef Tataki which arrived looking like a piece of art and was in the most amazing smoked ponzu. Followed by the pork belly in miso broth which was a delight to eat. Perfect amount of crackling on top and nice tender meat. My last savoury dish was Duck Leg with wild mushrooms and romanesco which was perfectly cooked and had fantastic flavour. For desert I went for the chocolate and peanut bar with ice cream. The most delicious desert I've had in a while. To finis the meal or waitress brought over two freshly baked French Madeleine's which were the perfect way to finish an amazing meal! They came out warm and smelling delicious and were light and fluffy. Mmm can you tell I enjoyed them! They were just beautiful.

X2SluJHW9cUSJMWlS-8cDg.text: The food was amazing. had the 4 courses octopus, chocolate peatnut dessertexquiste. special ocassion for my sis 21st/

rXq88LMn2tAAujlDm_1qQQ.text: I have to say from the get go.... Please don't see my three stars as negative and I will explain why.... Maze proudly wearing the name of Gordon Ramsay is a good restaurant and worth experiencing. Maze offers a touch of London fine dining and service. The staff are all delightful,  friendly,  helpful and professional. The chefs offer a great culinary experience with exciting flavors and twists.... But is it worth an M star? In my opinion... noRosettes yes definately... Maze felt more like an upmarket brand than a unique experience the Michelin movement commands. My girlfriend and I signed up for the seven course tasting menu,  with a few drinks (2) the bill weighed in at a couple hundred quid.... Did I feel like I received the enjoyment Maze should offer for in its price bracket?.... Yes and No. Worth a visit yes,  will I go back.... No. The feel of the restaurant,  lacking linen on tables and scratched plates (bad lighting) made the restaurant feel like an upmarket slightly tired Cafe. Good for a business lunch or casual meal but not much more. The wine selection was extensive and well thought through so full marks there. Also we were aloud to swap a dish on the tasting menu after the chef was asked which was really appreciated. Our tasting menu averaged 25 mins between courses, which is unacceptable for a 7 course tasting  menu, we were glad to leave after being in the restuarant for 2.5 hours. The food was interesting but not innovative, the restaurant was very very noisy and felt cluttered...... Something is missing.... Gordon maybe?? His name is on the door and I'm sure so is his influence... The venue lacked.... plain and simple. I recommend to go and experience "GRs" restaurant Maze... But maybe the head chef should put his name on the door... And unless you have three hours + to spend in a restaurant don't get the tasting menu, go for lunch...  order what catches your eye,  have a glass of top shelf wine and have a good time, but don't expect a Michelin star experience.

OONXKa-8JPT_9T31L8R3Ow.text: This is a truly amazing and price worthy place to eat if you are a meat lover like me. It's one of Gordon Ramays least fancy restaurants and the focus is all about grill - as it says in the name.The Wine ordering is done on iPads so you're always see the current price and which wines that are available i glass, and not just as bottle, just that moment.Then they bring you all the several meat choices and talk about the difference before you order.The meat it self is all of the highest standard and it's grilled to perfection. Just amazing.

Photo of maze Grill Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. The wine list, and ordering, is on an iPad

A3o6zc4SF9VPcFa-tHwMfg.text: You would think you get what you pay for but not in the case of Maze. I was excited to be able to try a Gordon Ramsey restaurant and see for myself the standard of perfection he demands of all his employees. I guess while the boss is away the employees will play. Service was just plain awful. We were seated promptly and given menus. The waiter came and asked us what wine we wanted. I was confused because there was no wine list in sight, was I supposed to just guess what was available? When I asked if there was a wine list the waiter disappeared and reappeared to shove an iPad in my face and walked away. No explanations.The sommelier. came by to help us with selecting a wine but he was quite pushy with wanting us to buy bottles. I'm not a big drinker and will usually only have a glass of wine. I could almost feel him mentally dismissing us when we started looking at glasses of wine.  While I came to Maze partially for the experience I was most excited for the food. The food was just okay, I've had much better for a 1/4 of the price and double the portion size. We were given amuze bouches which were a nice touch and some crackers with bean puree which was tasty. Each course could be eaten in 3 bites which may be forgivable since there were many courses. What wasn't forgivable was the pacing of the course. The wait between each course was about 20 minutes. Add on another 10 minutes just so someone can come and change your silverware. There was a silverware change between every single course. That's about a hour waiting just for silverware changes! Between every course we were just sitting there and while we enjoyed each others company it was getting very frustrating. When the manager asked us at the end of the meal if we enjoyed ourselves we told him honestly that we felt the pacing could have been better. We weren't looking for an apology or anything but we were shocked & insulted when he just looked at us an asked "Well, have you ever been to a restaurant of this caliber?". To answer your question sir: No, I have not, your restaurant is in a class all it's own. I have, however, been to restaurants with more stars and higher prices and also hole  in the wall restaurants with better service and spectacular food. TLDR: Poor service, average food, no bang for your buck. Instead you get sass for your cash.

LZKbdDzUEyzL1gt5rZ09yw.text: What can I say that haven't already been said? The food here is amazingly good! There were four of us that went and here is what we ordered:Marinated yellow fin tuna, Iberico ham, avocado purée, frozen apple, smoked ponzuDuck and foie gras terrine, black pepper poached pear, fresh walnuts, Sauternes gel Dumpling of lobster, tiger prawn and salmon, aromatic lemongrass broth Pork belly, razor clams, Savoy cabbage,  jalapeno and miso dressing Scottish hand - dived scallops, crushed butternut squash, lime leaf velouteDuck breast, steamed bun, sweet corn, fried onions and miso Crispy chicken thigh, crayfish, charred baby gem, turnip, lettuce mayonnaiseEvery dish was sooo yummy. My fav were the duck and foie gras, pork belly and yellow fin tuna. After the first round, we ordered more of the dishes we really liked.Desert was coffee and petite fours which were all fantastic. Walked out of there several hundred pounds lighter and full happy tummy. Next time I'm in London, I'll be back for sure!

FOmWRQ8QQtb6S9xgTW8Zyg.text: I am never one to be drawn to feel emotion when I am eating but it was the closest thing to a food orgasm in my mouth! If you are going to order the set menu, I highly recommend the cured salmon.Overall I enjoyed the experience and the staff and food were of a high standard. I think the restaurant decor itself seemed a bit stale.

tLS2D--DfCHwawGTfmd2Ug.text: In general, pretty happy with Maze; great food, great service overall. Went there for a business lunch, conveniently located close to our offices in Mayfair. We went 'a la carte', and ordered 7 dishes for the 2 of us, which was PLENTY.We started off with the 'Marinated yellow fin tuna, compressed apple, coriander, horseradish, ponzu sauce'. This was my least favourite dish... still, perfectly seared but nothing super special. Maybe too delicate for my pallet?The dashi braised octopus, heirloom tomatoes, rocket, ginger and soy dressing was super lovely.... the dashi is nicely umami, and the octopus has a beautiful crunch, the tomatoes taste fresh, and feel unworldly; best way I can describe it, sorry, it kind of left me speechless.The red mullet, crispy squid, garlic and lemon purée was also very good, and there was a nice playfulness between the mullet and the squid; great combination.The scottish hand - dived scallops, smoked bacon, black quinoa, broccoli and lemon was a highlight for me. The scallops were perfectly shallow fried, and it was a beautiful dish to look at; A+ for presentation, and A+ for taste. The dumpling of lobster, tiger prawns and salmon in aromatic lemongrass broth was an excellent choice, very delicate, but for 14£, I would have wanted more than 3...We had the Brill, brown shrimps, salsify, ginger,jalapeno and miso dressing; although the fish was perfectly cooked, and lovely, the shrimps were meh; the miso dressing was fantastic!The epic part of the meal was the braised beef feather blade, pomme purée, shimiji mushrooms, togarashi spice; the beef was soooo tender ! And the pomme puree was perfectly dense.We ended the meal with lemon tart, toasted meringue, crème fraîche sorbet,lemon sherbet. This dish is foreshadowed by a stunning teaser of lemon in nitrogen... the meringue is surprising... laid very flat, super delicate, and great taste. Perfect zing. Went down fast.The entire meal was supported by a bottle of Sancerre: Sancerre "Vignes Blanches", Henri Bourgeois 2011 for £45.00; crisp, fresh, and a beautiful wine to accompany our mostly sea food/fish centric selection.All in all, MAZE is a great place to take clients. Would I take someone there on a date? Probably not, there are funner, cooler places to have a social 1:1 (Texture, Dabbous), but for business and good food, this place rocks it.

IWpLtefzr0t0wsne5UTeCw.text: Had the special 4 courses for £24. Really good deal,  you can have ANY 4 dishes from the menu (so all savory or all sweet or a mix or the same dish 4 times!).Staff friendly, not overly attentive (good for me). Relaxing environment. The complementry bread was really good and the food fantastic. They are small tasters of the signature dishes. The wine list is presented on an ipad for you to browse through. Great idea but be carefull, the drinks will beef up your bill.  Service was very quick up until the 2nd course then we were left waiting around 30mins for the 3rd course...didn't bother us but the website did say that this offer was for those who were lunching in a hurry.....Overall, a great deal, grab it while you can!Also, I see the food catagory says American, the restaurant is actually French/Asian Cuisine. The grill next door is more American.

BhnQEJYs1h1m-nI7NA5akg.text: The steaks were amazing. Was there with a group of 30 people and the service was excellent. Even the Japanese with us thought the Sushi was excellent. Will surely return.

ZwZjqQExahLLBAkH9Z-H_w.text: Fantastic food, as expected from this Michelin-starred restaurant. Great fusion creation and interpretation of European and Asian dishes. Ingredients such as fish and garnishings were fresh. A definite culinary experience. The really amazing dish I had was the octopus interpretation - a beautiful Japanese and British culinary partnership executing a difficult ingredient extremely well. Amazing! The dessert I had was the frozen fraiche with whiskey sauce. You just gotta save your stomach for this. The dining experience is further enhanced with excellent service from the staff. Book ahead. Great stuff

5NPsJEgAdhiWmnItzlSDhA.text: This is probably one of the best dinner deals in London! We came here for the summer set course menu of 4 courses & a Bellini for 25£. Course 1: duck & foie gras terrine, cherries, wet almonds, Sautemes gel. Delicious!!!!! It paired well with the Rosé the sommelier recommended. Course 2: crispy chicken thigh, charred baby gem, turnip, lettuce mayonnaise. I loved the tenderness of the chicken & the crispy skin. It paired well with a sauvignon blanc.Course 3: braised beef feather blade, pomme purée, shimiji mushrooms, togarashi spice. Super tender. I hear they braised it for about 10 hours! Course 4: frozen banana, milk ice cream, banoffee caramel. A great way the end the meal. It was the perfect amount of sweetness. I also had a taste of the pork belly, razor clams, wasabi, crushed peas & the yuzu tea cake, mango & lime jam, lemongrass ice cream. The pork belly portion was huge! The skin was nice & crispy. I wished I had a choice to pick a 5th course! Pork belly is a must next time. The tea cake was light & reminded me of a moonpie. Overall I really had a good experience at the Maze. The service & staff were superb. I highly recommend coming here regardless if you get the summer deal or not. Make reservations!

NKXQ5bIz7WCMsf6Sqj_jzw.text: Had the set menu consisted 7 courses. Loved the foie gras and the lamb. My friend ordered beef tataki and It was the softest thing ever. Great dishes but not too spectacular. Good wine list we had two different Riesling to try priced at £125 and £58, pretty good right!? Good value food and services.

photos.caption: Photo of maze Grill Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

Bz5SK5R0l3EFnDM_7RTSVw.text: Fantastic evening with colleagues and a client. The food was very very good - an the many courses on the chef's menu built up and up in intensity and remarkability. The Cornish lamb was outstanding, as was the incredible chocolate delice. Ambience wise it's pretty suit-y and businessy, at least on a week night and I would say it was grown up, smart and comfortable rather than warm or intimate. Service was well drilled and discrete but not enormously charismatic - but certainly good enough. The wine list was intimidatingly pricey but the sommelier picked us very good Pinot noir and riesling to a more reasonable budget. All in, a fantastic spot for hosting and enjoying fine food.

cZ5gmoIiYUpLSszDxWLF9g.text: First, I must clarify that this review is for dining at Maze Grill and drinks at Maze. After watching what seems like hundreds of episodes of Ramsey's Kitchen Nightmares I was expecting everything to be even better than perfect although I was secretly hoping something would fall short. And although overall it was a great evening, a couple of things did fall short. I should have been delighted, but instead I felt a little jipped. The prices were pretty outrageous--about £100 a person. I'm accustomed to getting what I pay for and I'm not sure we really got what we paid for. The food was delicious and the wine was super. If you are a meat eater who particularly loves steak, you'll surely enjoy this spot. The meat was cooked perfectly and was so tender. I'm not a steak connoisseur, but I was with three boys who are and they were just dying in their chairs, making sure not to miss one scrap. They even had a cut of steak on the menu for £90... we didn't order that one, but since, I have wondered what makes it so special? They have an interesting way of doing starters. You can either order a traditional starter or you can share a bunch of small plates. Since small plates happen to be one of my all time favourite ways to dine, this pleased me to no end. We ordered all 7 that were on the menu and each was quite tastey. Some were better than others, but the one that would make me go back was the soft shell crab with spicy mayo. I could have been happy just having that and a glass of wine. The service was just okay for such a swanky place. They recommended way too many side orders for the table and a lot of food went to waste--in my book, it's really bad taste to waste--maybe it's a tactic to add just a few more £s onto your total bill. There were a couple sauces and dishes missed so we had to remind the waitress they were missing--poor form! And the man who was supposed to be the beef expert came to our table to tell us things "this is the Hereford beef. It is from Hereford." Like I didn't know that already... more time I will never get back! At the end of the evening they were kind enough to book us a table in the bar area--well, again maybe it was just a way to squeeze a few more £s out of our pockets. But it's a nice to be able to digest your food sitting down and in a well mannered bar before heading home.

3n2GpDr0DAYtMtYkiS8uew.text: Well I'm glad I wasn't paying, that's all I'll say.Oh ok I'll carry on for anyone interested.Went to maze for the first time after work with client and workmates. Got the chefs table which was nice. Slightly closed off and right by the kitchen so you see all the action.It's a very buzzy place which is kind of seductive too. So all good.Then the food came. It was a set menu for the table. Lots of starters. Crab cakes, deep fried szechuan ribs, risotto balls, chorizo, you get the picture. Lots of good old finger food to go with lots of beer and lots of chat. Only bad thing was that all of it was of a pretty poor standard. The risotto balls were heavy and doughy and felt like they had been hanging round for hours. The ribs were totally dry and overcooked and why they were covered in batter lord only knows. I think they were called Szechuan because there were a couple of slivers of onion and green pepper. Crab cakes, dry again. It felt suspiciously like everything had been made a dy or two before and cooked within an inch of it's life. The chorizo was tasty though.Next course was a choice of steak or chicken from the grill. My steak was not bad by any means but didn't delight like one at the hawksmoor might. And the chicken was again thoroughly overcooked. Puddings were piled high but lacked finesse.I dunno, maybe this isn't a finesse kind of place. But for the cash you expect something a lot better in terms of execution. Mr Ramsey hoisted by his own petard. We all imagined him coming in, kitchen nightmares stylee, taking one look at the ribs and saying "fuck me, fucking hell this is a shitfest. No authenticity, no passion from the kitchen, this place is going down the drain fast and no fucking mistake." unlucky Gordon. This place is one of yours!And on a smaller point, there was far far too much food, and I'm a greedy pig. The policy is obviously to produce quantity over quality and hope everyone leaves sated. Not for me. Shame. It's a buzzy place and the food let's it down badly. Surprised at all the high marks.

3q1NDHjtPpIHNe5zilFBEQ.text: I ate at the grill and found it to be pretty overpriced. We paid almost $100 each and did not even get salads or appetizers. We were hungry after dinner. The food was good but not "best meal of my life." Convenient since I was staying at the hotel, but not worth it.

lsFbHAKxSj8iguDZtiBV5Q.text: Chef's tasting menu + wine pairing + 2 more À la carte orders = awesome

U8tWmwV0-AM0MmW6pznjkg.text: Probably not the best choice following a week in Provence, my bad, but here we are...The food was good, but apart from the appetiser (scallops), I cannot recall what else was eaten, deer & pork cheek maybe, guess that the tell.Feels like Gordo's empire has grown beyond proper manageability...

jA941kEC_RQvLnAF5yT9OQ.text: 'The Dangerous Type'My dad suddenly developed an adventurous side and is rampantly living it out by exploring new restaurants, one of them being Gordon Ramsey's wacky 'Maze'. We were rather shocked soon after opening the menu:-Chinese style pork belly, braised pig's head, crackling, jasmine tea -Irish ox 'tongue 'n' cheek', caper raisin and ginger carrots, horseradish pomme puréRight...well then...I guess Gordon Ramsey was like, "Just how off the rocker can my menu possibly be whilst still enticing Londonites?" Apparently, you can never go too far if you're a celeb chef and his scheme totally worked. I was just a hamster in the maze, or an ox, or a skate, or a monkfish? Maze's stylish décor creates comfort in an other wise strange environment of audacious food and too many servers standing around with fancy dishes on their trays. The logo is very cool and can be seen everywhere from the floor pattern to the tables. To start off I had three scallops topped with granny smith apple, bacon, and butterscotch. WTF Gordon! I had the lamb dish with some other type of meat, and some other things on my plate I couldn't describe the taste or tell you the point of. The mashed potatoes were a cross between pudding and potatoes. I wasn't sure if they were the best potatoes I've ever had, or the worst. And The dessert. Oh the dessert! Definitely the best part, since we'd come this far I felt we had to see what the finishing touches were all about. And glad we did too because warm delicious chocolate cake thang with vanilla ice cream and some pistachio madness was smashing in top british style. Without ? the best 24 seconds of my day.  Top chef? hmm if you're into the wacky side of chef-ery then...sure.

0uZtLd3ql4tTnURbjT6izA.text: Is lunch for two ever worth £125? This is a bigger question than we have the time or space to discuss in this review. Lunch at Maze was very expensive. The food was very good, and if you're looking to go to a Gordon Ramsay restaurant, you might as well give it a go. Maze's buzz is English cuisine with an Asian twist in the form of small plates. One of the dishes I got was braised octopus, oxtail vinaigrette, dehydrated black olive, fine herbs and confit lemon--you can definitely taste both the English and Asian influences. The presentation was the high point of the meal for me. The dishes were outrageously good-looking and ridiculous. Tiny scoops of bloody mary sorbet, a few tiny spoons of caviar, eel "scratchings"--each plate was designed to look like modern art. But although beautiful and very interesting, I didn't think the taste quite lived up to the looks. It was good, but it wasn't life changing. The service was perfect, although I do think they suggested we order more than we needed. We ended up with three dishes each (they recommended 4) plus 2 desserts and wine. £125 for a 2 person lunch is a lot. I'm still at a point in my life where if I spend that much on a meal I want my entire world to be rocked and for me to walk out of the restaurant a changed person. 3.5 stars but rounding up because of the rose jelly candy at the end.

80iB71ZWk6I3LKEqM880Tw.text: Great steaks. However, I find it ironic that a Gordon Ramsey restaurant only scores 2 out of 5 (5 is best) on food hygiene inspection!  I kid you not!  Www.food.gov.uk/ratings

j44A_m9901_IHk8XHFyV_w.text: Maze Grill is a pretty standard steakhouse / grill. Service was good and food was good but nothing really blew my mind.  I thought the decor was a little bland

vGIvj_IvN3-hym2_JYrVcA.text: There are many different dishes that you can choose from but what I liked most was the duck with rice around it. It is a classy restaurant with amazing food

8L3vpgSl2kIWyjbT-eVPUA.text: I had my first (of hopefully many) Maze experiences this past week and was pretty impressed. A nice dressy casual and relaxed restaurant with a large assortment of small plates to choose from.Instead of the prix fixe "chef's menu", our group ended up ordering a la carte off the "tasting" menu, each with four courses. The portions were generally small, maybe 4-5 bites each, but each bite was exquisite. Each of the dishes had a main element with some sort of innovative accent. Example: pan fried daurade with lobster risotto, crispy grey shrimp, fennel confit. It's a mouthful both to say and a great mouthful to eat.Loved the gratis dessert bites of baked alaska lollipops, chocolate truffles, white chocolate covered raspberries, chocolate pistachios, and a rose turkish delight type confection.Service was competent and unobtrusive.

EnK8_rBolgkJNJvFxtA1Pw.text: Went for lunch with chums. Discreet entrance actually in the corner of Grosvenor Sq. (ignore current Qype map). Friendly greeting by staff and nice waiting area where you can sit and chat while the group arrives. Modern, not-to-harsh dining area with nicely spaced tables. An interesting menu with two offerings, Tapas style English dishes where you can choose the number of courses and a flight of wines to accompany.You then choose the actual dishes (two puds-yum if you want!). The other half of the menu is a list of more substantial courses. Very satisfied with what arrived on the plate, though could fault soup as it was over salted, and the 'roast' salmon was cold & 'raw' in the centre, though tasty not my style. The other plates were absolutely spot on and delicious. Had the forced Rhubarb for health reasons(!). Wine we ordered separately and so I did not choose, but a good Viognier (2 off) and a very nice red from Portugal got us up to £270 for 4. Hic. Very good fun.

7ugA1JQ9-hzC1fybwgtaog.text: When I first went to the Maze, about a year and a half ago, I had just arrived in London, and didn't know anything about Gordon Ramsay. I just stumbled upon the restaurant one day I was in Mayfair with some friends  visiting from Italy and followed the (very good) TimeOut guide.Maze turned out to be an amazing restaurant, where I've been at least four other times since then, as I tend to bring there all the people that comes visiting from Italy (normally not thinking that food is one of the things why someone would visit London).The quality of the dishes is extraordinary: some of the matchings are simple genius, and in general over the course of a full meal one experiences some of the more intense and pleasurable gustatory sensations that can happen.The way the menu is organized is interesting as well: they have three different possibilities: a 5-course tasting menu (of the tapa-sized dishes, see below), a normal "carte" where one chooses entree - main - dessert, or a set of tapa-sized dishes meant to be taken in a number of 4-5 for a complete meal. I normally go for this last possibility because I'm more interested in variety than in quantity: while the quality is always amazing, though, the last time I went there I felt that 5 dishes hadn't been enough for filling me, and the final £80 pp bill convinced me that in these hard times I'd better lower my culinary needs (and this is where the 4* comes from). Prices are around that value if you get lured by one of their excellent sommeliers into buying one of the very good wines they have on their wine list. It might be interesting to know that, at least until last year, at noon the 5 courses tasting menu became a 3-courses one, much cheaper and still a very good opportunity to taste some of their extraordinary preparations.Also, I sometimes popped up there with no reservation, and even if the place was full I could be arranged for a couple of seatings at the bar: it might be worth it (service is just as good), and if you can be put on the two sides of a corner you can still look in the eyes of the person you're eating with. ;)Ambiance: great. Service: great. Quality: great. Only gripe (and only once or twice): the amount of food you get with 5 tapa-sized dishes.

qSD9lEPCelp1BRtiX7khwg.text: I was really hoping that this was going to be 5 stars in my book, but I have to say I was disappointed.I've been to top restaurants in New York and San Francisco and this just didn't quite add up.I appreciate the whole concept of tastings and tapas style, but the tiny tiny portions at very high prices were just not as mind-blowing as I had hoped.The service was just ok--not as on top of it as I hoped...always asking for water or to remind them about our wine order.Desserts were disprorportionately large and the chocolate granache was very disappointing--just a slab of chocolate.Not giving up on Gordon Ramsey's restaurants, but this one is not getting my highest marks.

KMchx_bML16Ex5bTRDUtsA.text: Phenomenal! I've been to many restaurants and eateries around the world and this is by far the best steak.  My wife and I had a wonderful time.  The food and the ambiance was top notch.

pyYrBK_DvCDfiOffUwroIg.text: So, this is actually a flashback to probably the worst restaurant I've ever been to. Since this comical experience it may have completely changed and is actually good, but I just figured I'd share it with you for a laugh. I took notes at the time so it should be a fairly accurate recount.The front of house/maître d' staff were excellent. Friendly, helpful and accommodating. Now, if my mum taught me not to say anything when I have nothing nice to say, this little review would end here. You'd expect a prime time TV, celebrity chef like 'Gordon Ramsay' to establish a restaurant that serves delicious and inventive food. Don't be fooled people! Do NOT be fooled.I first began to question whether something might be very wrong when a waiter brought out the wine list displayed on his iPod. Um, why? Just why? It is neither cute nor cool. If the reason you go out to eat is for the posh setting, insincerely polite waiter staff, a nice ambiance and the décor you may love Maze. If you go out to eat for the food, you may not. It was inexcusable!I'm going to try to keep this as friendly as possible. So, in the spirit of things I've edited out most of the original notes, but have left in these pointers: Don't serve me soggy wonton-like dumplings with no detectable flavour aside from salt floating in what tastes, looks and smells like a bit of soy sauce in very watered down Knorr chicken stock. Don't pretend that any kind of banana cake is supposed to taste like a dry slice of unbuttered brown bread because it just so isn't. Under no circumstances should you place a dry chicken piece with half a broken bone left in it next to a fried flake of chicken skin, put that dirty duo onto a plate, and then have that plate placed in front of me. KFC is probably laughing at you. Lastly, try to avoid your beef and mash tasting like you picked it fresh from Asda's 'Taste the Difference' range. I honestly wish I was exaggerating, alas I am not.Even the presentation of the dishes was painfully average. It was like the effort was made to make it look like 'fine dining', but like the genuine creativity and passion that goes into producing a beautiful plate of food took the evening off.I will say though, I'm no wine buff but the wines that were matched to our courses were delicious. (Despite them not actually matching the courses. Never mind.)Bottom line.. don't trust celebrity chefs. A disgusted 2.9 out of 10. Sort it out Gordon.faraohofphood.blogspot.c…  FOLLOW MY FOOD BLOGFaraoh of Phood

6KDDzWnOeAr_iflt3zED2Q.text: Went their last week for lunch. I wasn't that hungry so I ordered the butternut squash soup.  It was very good- could have used a little more seasoning but was happy to note that it was not cream based and tasted quite fresh.  The potion size was quite large so that was all I had. I would go back to try more dishes.

EnRXFC9XLNnY6ozytWErjg.text: So I will preface by saying I did not know that this was Gordon Ramsey's Restaurant before going there so i didnt have elevated expectations or anything.  I will also state than in the interest of full disclosure I am a big Fan of Mr Ramsey's tv shows and have eaten at some of his other places.   There are two sides to this restaurant Maze and Maze Grill, I had dinner at Maze Grill and just drinks at Maze.So I opted for a steak (Filet Mignon) at Maze Grill and while it was cooked correctly (Medium Rare) I found the meat to be very tough, I have had many better steaks in my life (for a lot cheaper too).  Under normal circumstances I would have sent that steak back but happened to be in a rushThe Bar side Maze was pretty cool, we went their for drinks before and after dinner and it was a cool and relaxed atmosphere.  I learned upon my return to the states that Maze is owned by GM and I thought to myself no way, he has such high standards for taste and quality control......perhaps I just got a bad piece of meat?

PuKHA_cs0gHYiDHPGfi75w.text: Ambiance: Surprisingly casual. I made it in for a dinner on Sunday wearing a t-shirt and didn't feel out of place. You'd probably feel more comfortable in something collared but it's not mandatory. Warm atmosphere.Food: I'm not sure what everyone's raving about, but compared to restaurants of similar price/quality, this isn't anything to write home about. The steaks were good but not great--there's a wide-ranging selection, but both steaks my table ordered came underseasoned and undercooked. The sauces that accompany them were butter-heavy and uninspiring. The sides were ordered were good, but not particularly imaginative. One of us had the burger, which was pretty good, but not as good as the ones at Bar Boulud (while being a few pounds more expensive). Desserts were similarly underwheming--the apple crumble was scalding hot when we received it (but not bad once it cooled, which took a long while), and the chocolate/marshmallow/brownie dessert was bland: sure, all the pieces were there, but it tasted like sugar and butter. The brownie was dry and didn't have enough chocolate in it and the rest was pretty boilerplate. I guess that would sum up the food: by-the-book. Uninspiring. Not bad, but doesn't live up to the reputation.Service: Two of our starters were mixed up and our waiter was slightly clumsy--he poured the soup inattentively, drowning the croutons and garnish. We had to flag people down for water a couple of times, too--not what you expect in this kind of place.Value: Too expensive for what it is. Try Bar Boulud or Goodman--better food and better value. Conclusion: better value for money can be had elsewhere. The food is decent but not very creative. I expected better and was a little disappointed, especially when the bill came.

HR3ryymJXAxat0TZdEOL7g.text: The food tastes as good as the pictures!  Got a variety of dishes on the a la carte meme to share.  Classy place and attentive service. Best of all was our surprise meeting of Gordon Ramsay!

j06Lfbm51ztsO_rMm6mAvg.text: Wow! I was aMAZEd by this place! haha The restaurant looks small but its quite big inside, I went there with my friend and we had a great time together, no rush or anything. The decoration is beautiful and simple the food is very good, but small as well so make sure to have at least 3 plate for each and good thing is that you can share and try a variety of they dishes plus this was by far one of the best services I experienced in London, they know everything perfectly and they way they describe not only the food but also they champagne and they wine they have is irresistible!I would recommend this place to go with friends and family and I think it's a perfect place to go if you have something to celebrate The Maze makes everything more especial.

photos.caption: Photo of maze Grill Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

q2E-NYL3fFNAo-iKCxAHiQ.text: After completely blown away by his flagship restaurant, I was super curious to try Maze. Got this opentable deal, 35pound for 4 courses with Bellini for dinner, so no brainer, I was in. Ordered the beef tataki, octopus, pork and chocolate dessert (can't remember exactly what). The only let down was the pork, was pretty disappointed considering usually you can't get wrong with pork too much. But one miss out of four, it was forgiven. I loved the texture on the octopus, not chewy and very soft, just what I expected. The asian flavored beef tataki was excellent too, with nice soy-sauce like and hot pepper. The amuse bouche was okay, there were 3 /4 being served, but one in particular stroke me was this pork skin cracker or whatever they called it. It was just one out of many cracker / chips in the basket, but it stood out to me. Delicious. I was dining solo, so the server probably did not want to bother me too much and wanted to leave me in peace with my inner self. But it almost got too cold, functional and not as friendly as I expected it to be. But overall, for that price, i was satisfied.

cGCmy1cr3xTn0MyX3UT7xQ.text: Good . . . genuinely good . . . but not even close to great. I wanted so much more for this Gordon Ramsay restaurant. Alas - I was surely underwhelmed. Partly it was my fault. I went without a reservation and ended up at the bar (along with three other single American men - ha). The service was - forgetful to say the least. Every item I ordered was re-requested by the server some 5-minutes after the original order. Then, after having ordered "chips" for my meal - they were completely forgotten. In defense of good customer service, the chips were scratched from the final bill - but still, a top notch place like the Maze Grill should have bar service down to a science.Two things stick out - the bar-back who washed over 1-million glasses while I sat awaiting my food sipping my club soda was a delightful man of African decent who made every effort to make me comfortable (indeed, he was really the only one that gave me any attention); and, number two - the Austrian Pinot Noir the sommelier recommended was dynamite. Otherwise - the meal I had in Austin, Texas last week far outshines the meal I had at Maze Grill.Parting notes - there are much better places in a foodie city like London to drop 75 pounds for a seat a the bar.

lOXZbv7kMxv8zGyP3DBsCg.text: The family and I decided to have Christmas Day dinner at the Maze Grill..... not sure it was my best $800 investment for six people this Christmas. Food was tasty, but not "exceptional".... additionally all the food, across all three courses was served "warm", not served hot. Really surprised as the restaurant had so many staff on duty. The staff appeared to be working "for the extra Christmas money" as they had to be asked three times for basic items, more gravy, a knife, salt and pepper. Restaurant setting looked as if it had been styled by "IKEA", not the high end standard I was expecting from the man who has lots to say about life, and the restaurant business...... Deserts where the finishing touch, three of my party ordered the "Apple Tart" which was served upon a paper thin pastry crust, with burnt edges and one apple slice constituting the fruit...... I am embarrassed for the execution ! Thanks, but we will not be back any time soon.

dIGqisX6DRnFvLiQzhohDg.text: The atmosphere is beautiful and my cauliflower salad was interesting and flavorful.  Actually all of the starters looked great including a sizable Cobb salad and a spicy prawn dish.  Prawns were much smaller than I have ever seen in the US but this was the second nice restaurant with small prawns so maybe it is a London thing?  I had to knock a few starts because my pasta was so overcooked.  The flavor was good but it was a little hard to get past the mush.  I liked that the menu was eclectic.  In my party one had sushi, one had ribs, another had pasta, another steak.

VeqgFrNHw5uKSEoNmfWXxg.text: Out of respect for Gordon, we gave it a 3 star. My medium rare British sirloin was over cooked, dry and flavorless. The veal carpaccio is interesting, but also flavorless without the fried kale.

DLpmqPc-Eo9hs2ac7xtlkQ.text: After spending a couple of days in London for our honeymoon, my wife and I decided to dine at Gordon's Maze Grill restaurant. For starters we ordered the schezuan pepper squid and I ordered the dried head and meat platter. Both were very tasty. My wife ordered the lobster and I went for the lamb chops with sides of baby potatoes and portebello mushrooms. Everything was excellent! The service was great! I would have gave the meal 5 stars but Gordon never came out of the kitchen and 'told me to piss off'!
